subtitles.transcript: I don’t remember whether it was the BP or the Novartis one, but there was a degree of control
over publications in research and they would be able to sort of put any sort of findings they didn’t like on hold
for up to a certain amount of time – it was one or two years – and so the ability for private industry to say,
you know, “This is not convenient for us. You don’t get to publish this for a year or two.”
That’s a massive problem, right? And so it totally undermines the integrity of that work and the integrity of the people
doing that work and there was a lot of critique of the UC Berkeley professors who decided to take on this contract.
For them, they saw this as an enormous amount of money that no one else was getting and sort of –
You wave the gold coins in front of people and it’s really tempting. So I think that’s a real danger.
Fundamentally this undermines the public mission of the university and that’s one of the sort of, for me, the core dangers
is that having research funded by private industry oriented toward their own private interests is not…
it’s very different from the public interest. Sort of conflating private interests and public interests is a major problem.
